para.paratext: Another welcome change under the new Evidence Code is the presumption under O.C.G.A. § 24-10-1003 that copies are acceptable absent a genuine question as to the authenticity of the original or a circumstance which makes it unfair to admit a duplicate instead of an original. This Code section provides as follows:
A duplicate shall be admissible to the same extent as an original unless:
A genuine question is raised as to the authenticity of the original; or
A circumstance exists where it would be unfair to admit the duplicate in lieu of the original.[1]

Thus, the Georgia Supreme Court has permitted screen shots of text messages that appeared on a cell phone, reasoning that where no genuine issue exists as to the authenticity of the original, and no circumstance exists where it would be unfair to admit a duplicate instead of an original, then the photograph of what appeared on the screen was analogous to a printout readable by sight and therefore admissible to the same extent of an original within the meaning of the statute.[2]

In Leslie v. Doe, 326 Ga. App. 154, 756 S.E.2d 238 (2014), the Court of Appeals reversed the grant of summary judgment where the trial court failed to consider a copy of an affidavit given by a witness where the opposing party did not object on best evidence grounds. Note that this case was decided under the old Evidence Code.
